questions.Q: The resultant of the four vectors is:

A.opt: 12 cm and points along the positive y-axis
6 cm and points along the positive y-axis
6 cm and points along the negative y-axis
12 cm and points along the negative y-axis

questions.E: The x components of the upper vectors cancel each other. The same happens for the two lower vectors. The only surviving cooponents are the vertical ones, so that the magnitude of the resultant vector is 12 cm and points along the positive y-axis.

questions.Q: The resultant of the four vectors is:

A.opt: 12 cm and points along the positive y-axis
6 cm and points along the positive y-axis
6 cm and points along the negative y-axis
12 cm and points along the negative y-axis

questions.E: The x components of the upper vectors cancel each other. The same happens for the two lower vectors. The only surviving cooponents are the vertical ones, so that the magnitude of the resultant vector is 12 cm and points along the positive y-axis.

questions.Q: The magnitude of three mutually perpendicular forces $$\vec {F}_1$$, $$\vec {F}_2$$ and $$\vec {F}_3$$ are 2, 10 and 11 N respectively. Then the magnitude of its resultant is:
questions.E: The resultant force is $$\vec{F}=\vec{F}_1+\vec{F}_3+\vec{F}_3$$ where $$|\vec{F}_1|=2\,\text{N}$$, $$|\vec{F}_2|=10\,\text{N}$$ and $$|\vec{F}_1|=11\,\text{N}$$.  $$\Rightarrow \, |\vec{F}|=\sqrt{|\vec{F}_1|^2+|\vec{F}_2|^2+|\vec{F}_3|^2}=\sqrt{(2\,\text{N})^2+(10\,\text{N})^2+(11\,\text{N})^2}=\sqrt{225\,\text{N}^2}=15\,\text{N}$$

questions.Q: The magnitude of two mutually perpendicular forces $$\vec {F}_1$$ and $$\vec {F}_2$$ are 2.0 and 10.0 N respectively. Then the magnitude of its resultant is:
questions.E: The resultant force is $$\vec{F}=\vec{F}_1+\vec{F}_2$$ where $$|\vec{F}_1|=2\,\text{N}$$ and  $$|\vec{F}_2|=10\,\text{N}$$.  $$\Rightarrow\,|\vec{F}|=\sqrt{|\vec{F}_1|^2+|\vec{F}_2|^2}=\sqrt{(2.0\,\text{N})^2+(10.0\,\text{N})^2}=\sqrt{104.0\,\text{N}^2}=10.2\,\text{N}$$

questions.Q: Forces $$\vec{F}_1$$ and $$\vec{F}_2$$ act on a point mass in two mutually perpendicular directions. The magnitude of the resultant force on the point mass will be:
questions.E: The resultant force is $$\vec{F}=\vec{F}_1+\vec{F}_2$$ and its magnitude is $$\Rightarrow\,|\vec{F}|=\sqrt{|\vec{F}_1|^2+|\vec{F}_2|^2}$$

questions.Q: A unit vector $$\hat{r}$$ pointing from point $$A=(1,2,3)$$ to point $$B=(2,5,7)$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that a unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$  is built as $$\\ \hat{r}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$\\ \vec{R}=(2-1)\hat{i}+(5-2)\hat{j}+(7-3)\hat{k}=\hat{i}+3\hat{j}+4\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{1^2+3^2+4^2}=\sqrt{26}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{r}=\frac{\hat{i}+3\hat{j}+4\hat{k}}{\sqrt{26}}$$

questions.Q: A unit vector $$\hat{r}$$ pointing from point $$A=(2,5,7)$$ to point $$B=(1,2,3)$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that a unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$  is built as $$\\ \hat{r}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$\\ \vec{R}=(1-2)\hat{i}+(2-5)\hat{j}+(3-7)\hat{k}=-\hat{i}-3\hat{j}-4\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(-1)^2+(-3)^2+(-4)^2}=\sqrt{26}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{r}=-\frac{\hat{i}+3\hat{j}+4\hat{k}}{\sqrt{26}}$$

questions.Q: A unit vector $$\hat{a}$$ parallel and pointing in the same direction of the vector $$\vec{a}=2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}+\hat{k}$$ is:
questions.E: Recall that a unit vector parallel and pointing in the same direction of the vector $$\vec{a}$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{a}=\frac{\vec{a}}{|\vec{a}|}\\$$ In our case $$\\ \vec{a}=2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}+\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{a}|=\sqrt{2^2+3^2+1^2}=\sqrt{14}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{a}=\frac{2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}+\hat{k}}{\sqrt{14}}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(1,0,0)$$ and $$B=(0,2,1)$$ $$\\ \vec{R}=(0-1)\hat{i}+(2-0)\hat{j}+(1-0)\hat{k}=-\hat{i}+2\hat{j}+1\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(-1)^2+(2)^2+(1)^2}=\sqrt{6}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{-\hat{i}+2\hat{j}+1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}} $$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(0,2,1)$$ and $$B=$$(1,0,0) $$\\ \vec{R}=(1-0)\hat{i}+(0-2)\hat{j}+(0-1)\hat{k}=\hat{i}-2\hat{j}-1\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(1)^2+(-2)^2+(-1)^2}=\sqrt{6}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\hat{i}-2\hat{j}-1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(0,0,1)$$ and $$B=$$(1,2,0) $$\\ \vec{R}=(1-0)\hat{i}+(2-0)\hat{j}+(0-1)\hat{k}=\hat{i}+2\hat{j}-1\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(1)^2+(2)^2+(-1)^2}=\sqrt{6}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\hat{i}+2\hat{j}-1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{6}}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(1,0,1)$$ and $$B=$$(0,2,1) $$\\ \vec{R}=(0-1)\hat{i}+(2-0)\hat{j}+(1-1)\hat{k}=-\hat{i}+2\hat{j}+0\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(-1)^2+(2)^2+(0)^2}=\sqrt{5}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{-\hat{i}+2\hat{j}}{\sqrt{5}}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(1,2,0)$$ and $$B=$$(0,2,1) $$\\ \vec{R}=(0-1)\hat{i}+(2-2)\hat{j}+(1-0)\hat{k}=-\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+1\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(-1)^2+(0)^2+(1)^2}=\sqrt{2}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{-\hat{i}+\hat{k}}{\sqrt{2}}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(1,0,0)$$ and $$B=$$(0,0,1) $$\\ \vec{R}=(0-1)\hat{i}+(0-0)\hat{j}+(1-0)\hat{k}=-\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+1\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(-1)^2+(0)^2+(1)^2}=\sqrt{2}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{-\hat{i}+\hat{k}}{\sqrt{2}}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(1,2,0)$$ and $$B=$$(1,0,1) $$\\ \vec{R}=(1-1)\hat{i}+(0-2)\hat{j}+(1-0)\hat{k}=0\hat{i}-2\hat{j}+1\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(0)^2+(-2)^2+(1)^2}=\sqrt{5}\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{-2\hat{j}+\hat{k}}{\sqrt{5}}$$

questions.Q: The figure shows a parallelepiped of sides $$a=1$$, $$b=2$$ and $$c=1$$. If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are points, the unit vector $$\hat{u}$$ that points from $$A$$ to $$B$$ is:
questions.E: A unit vector pointing from point $$A=(x_1,y_1,z_1)$$ to point $$B=(x_2,y_2,z_2)$$ is built as $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\vec{R}}{|\vec{R}|}\\$$ where $$\vec{R}=(x_2-x_1)\hat{i}+(y_2-y_1)\hat{j}+(z_2-z_1)\hat{k}$$. In our case $$A=(1,0,0)$$ and $$B=$$(1,0,1) $$\\ \vec{R}=(1-1)\hat{i}+(0-0)\hat{j}+(1-0)\hat{k}=0\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+1\hat{k}\\$$ So, $$|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{(0)^2+(0)^2+(1)^2}=1\\$$ Hence, $$\\ \hat{u}=\frac{\hat{k}}{1}=\hat{k}$$

questions.Q: The vector which is equal to $$\overrightarrow{BC}+\overrightarrow{CA}$$ is:
questions.E: Using the polygon method to add vectors: $$\overrightarrow{BA}$$

questions.Q: The vector which is equal to $$\overrightarrow{BA}+\overrightarrow{AE}+\overrightarrow{EC}$$ is:
questions.E: Using the polygon method to add vectors: $$\overrightarrow{BC}$$

questions.Q: The vector which is equal to $$\overrightarrow{AB}+\overrightarrow{BC}+\overrightarrow{CD}$$ is:
questions.E: Using the polygon method to add vectors: $$-\overrightarrow{DA}$$

questions.Q: The vector which is equal to $$\overrightarrow{AB}+\overrightarrow{BC}+\overrightarrow{CD}+\overrightarrow{DE}$$ is:
questions.E: Using the polygon method to add vectors: $$-\overrightarrow{EA}$$

questions.Q: The vector $$\overrightarrow{RS}$$ in terms of $$\vec{r}$$, $$\vec{s}$$ and $$\vec{t}$$ is:
questions.E: $$\overrightarrow{RS}=\overrightarrow{RO}+\overrightarrow{OS}=-\overrightarrow{OR}+\overrightarrow{OS}=-\vec{r}+\vec{s}=\vec{s}-\vec{r}$$

questions.Q: The vector $$\overrightarrow{SR}$$ in terms of $$\vec{r}$$, $$\vec{s}$$ and $$\vec{t}$$ is:
questions.E: $$\overrightarrow{SR}=\overrightarrow{SO}+\overrightarrow{OR}=-\overrightarrow{OS}+\overrightarrow{OR}=-\vec{s}+\vec{r}=\vec{r}-\vec{s}$$

questions.Q: The vector $$\overrightarrow{ST}$$ in terms of $$\vec{r}$$, $$\vec{s}$$ and $$\vec{t}$$ is:
questions.E: $$\overrightarrow{ST}=\overrightarrow{SO}+\overrightarrow{OT}=-\overrightarrow{OS}+\overrightarrow{OT}=-\vec{s}+\vec{t}=\vec{t}-\vec{s}$$

questions.Q: Based on the figure, the one  correct vector equation is:
questions.E: Taking into account the polygone method to add vectors it is clear from the figure that: $$\vec{R}=\vec{p}+\vec{q}=\vec{r}+\vec{s}+\vec{t}\Rightarrow \vec{p}=\vec{r}+\vec{s}+\vec{t}-\vec{q}$$

questions.Q: Based on the figure, the one  correct vector equation is:
questions.E: Using the polygone method: $$\vec{R}=\vec{u}+\vec{p}-\vec{q}+\vec{r}=\vec{t}+\vec{s}$$

questions.Q: Based on the figure, the one  correct vector equation is:
questions.E: Taking into account the polygone method to add vectors it is clear from the figure that: $$\vec{R}=-\vec{x}+\vec{y}-\vec{p}-\vec{q}+\vec{r}+\vec{s}=\vec{w}+\vec{v}+\vec{u}-\vec{t}    \therefore \vec{y}+\vec{r}+\vec{s}+\vec{t}=\vec{p}+\vec{q}+\vec{u}+\vec{v}+\vec{w}+\vec{x}$$

questions.Q: The cuboid $$ABCDEFGH$$ shown has $$\overrightarrow{AB}=\vec{a}$$, $$\overrightarrow{AD}=\vec{b}$$ and $$\overrightarrow{AE}=\vec{c}\text{.}$$ The vector $$\overrightarrow{AG}$$ in terms of $$\vec{a}$$, $$\vec{b}$$ and $$\vec{c}$$ is:
questions.E: Using the polygone method to add vectors: $$\overrightarrow{AG}=\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}$$

questions.Q: The cuboid $$ABCDEFGH$$ shown has $$\overrightarrow{AB}=\vec{a}$$, $$\overrightarrow{AD}=\vec{b}$$ and $$\overrightarrow{AE}=\vec{c}\text{.}$$ The vector $$\overrightarrow{BH}$$ in terms of $$\vec{a}$$, $$\vec{b}$$ and $$\vec{c}$$ is:
questions.E: Using the polygone method to add vectors: $$\overrightarrow{BH}=\vec{b}+\vec{c}-\vec{a}$$
